title: Wednesday, 13th September, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Hi

PM11:01am

Don't say you weren't warned Tinhat

PM11:02am

https://www.esma.e...ties_no.2_2017.pdf

11:02 am
PM11:02am

Don't worry you don't actually have to read the 87 page doc there

PM11:02am

It's just ESMA warning of heightened market risks

PM11:03am

ESMA sees valuation risk at highest levels due to financial weakness and geopolitical uncertainty

11:03 am
PM11:03am

That's the headline

PM11:03am

Anyone taking any notice of that?

PM11:03am

Not really

11:04 am
PM11:04am

Let me get an unrelated pic of the day

PM11:04am

PM11:04am

Jian Yang

11:04 am
PM11:04am

He's at the centre of this intriguing story

PM11:04am

https://www.ft.com...-a652-cde3f882dd7b

PM11:05am

From Jamil Anderlini

11:05 am
PM11:05am

Sitting New Zealand MP suspected of being a Chinese spy.

PM11:05am

Interested in what people think of that

PM11:06am

If you read the comments, there's loads of people screaming that there's no firm evidence in the story that he is a spy.

11:07 am
PM11:07am

But do people really think the FT would print a story like that -- and give it such prominence -- unless there was real concern?

PM11:07am

I don't know

PM11:07am

I will try and concentrate on markets instead

11:07 am
undefined
PM11:08am

It's a bit mixed and somewhat dull

PM11:08am

Is that just me Bryce

11:07 am
PM11:08am

Jaded

BE11:08am

That may well be the case. The main theme we have is sterling rallying like billy-o.

BE11:08am

Which explains nearly everything.

11:09 am
PM11:09am

It's come off the boil just recently tho i think

BE11:09am

That's post the UK wage growth figures.

PM11:09am

Yeah\

11:09 am
PM11:09am

Still, 1.3260...

BE11:10am

Which is very nearly a 52-week high, without which we'd be more or less flat, so let's ignore that for a bit.

BE11:11am

ROTR are talking Apple, inevitably, because I guess there's not enough coverage already on the internet of a product update by the world's biggest toy manufacturer.

11:11 am
PM11:11am

You are always so grumpy about Apple

BE11:11am

It's a one-product company. It's dull.

BE11:11am

We can, in the tiny hope of adding some value, go through the supplier network.

11:11 am
BE11:12am

Goldman Sachs has a lovely chart .....

BE11:12am

BE11:12am

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Which is the 50-odd companies existing on Apple's back.

BE11:12am

A green apple is "Strength in the Apple profit pool"

BE11:12am

Red apple is "Defending the Apple profit pool"

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Green blob is "Expanding non-Apple business in key growth areas"

PM11:12am

ok

BE11:12am

Red blob is "Slowly developing non-Apple business in key growth areas"

11:12 am
BE11:13am

And dollars are dollars. 2016 combined sales to Apple, as per GS.

BE11:13am

So, in terms of what was announced last night .... we knew nearly all of it.

BE11:13am

That giant supplier network now leaks like a kitchen utensil so we know nearly everything these days.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

So ..... it's more a case of good/bad news confirmed rather than anything price sensitive.

BE11:14am

Here's Kepler.

BE11:14am

STMicroelectronics (Hold, TP USD15.7) should benefit from a material sales pick-up in Q3 (sales up 16.6% YOY, thanks to the ramp-up of its 3D sensing technology in the iPhone X, Time-of-Flight likely in all devices and potentially new MEMS), while the trends as of Q4 will depend on the commercial success of the devices.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

AMS (non-rated) should benefit from the ramp-up of its True Tone sensor in all new iPhones and wafer level optics (WLO) in the iPhone X, while Dialog (non-rated) is mainly geared toward global iPhone volumes and higher semi content (with potentially two chips in the new iPhones vs. one in the previous devices).

BE11:14am

And Exane.

BE11:14am

The standout winners for us in the iPhone X are STM and AMS. Both are involved in supplying 3D sensing components into the iPhone X. We reiterate our 3D sensing ASP assumptions for STM of $5-7 and AMS of $3-4. Still not yet clear where each 3D sensing component fits into the new iPhone X. We await teardowns post Nov-3 for more detail on specific wins.

11:14 am
BE11:15am

We think Soitec (+) has also benefited as we believe the 3D sensing image sensor is based on SOI wafers. Elsewhere we believe DLG (+) has increased its power management content (PMIC chip) across all new iPhones, and we model +10% y/y content growth. Further, we expect QCOM (=) / Intel (=) to continue to share the LTE socket, depending on geography, with CEVA (+) supplying the 4G baseband IP to Intel. Only slight negative we would highlight at this point is the Nov-3 shipment date is a week later than we had expected, so perhaps 6m units lower, equating to c.$42m for STM and $22m for AMS.

BE11:15am

Then, of course, there's IQE.

IQE PLC (IQE:LSE): Last: 139.31, down 7.69 (-5.23%), High: 148.00, Low: 135.75, Volume: 7.38m
11:15 am
BE11:15am

We've somehow avoided talking about vertical-cavity surface-emitting lasers for the past few months.

BE11:15am

Even though IQE's up something like 1 billion per cent this year.

BE11:15am

Here's Wikipedia: https://en.wikiped...ace-emitting_laser

11:15 am
BE11:16am

The vertical-cavity surface-emitting laser, or VCSEL ˈvɪksəl, is a type of semiconductor laser diode with laser beam emission perpendicular from the top surface, contrary to conventional edge-emitting semiconductor lasers (also in-plane lasers) which emit from surfaces formed by cleaving the individual chip out of a wafer.

BE11:16am

So. As I understand it, you need this stuff to make the PrimeSense stuff work.

BE11:16am

Primesense is the stuff Apple bought back in 2013 that bounces infrared out of the camera to detect the depth of objects.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

It's kinda like an update of the Polaroid Sonar cameras from the 1970s (that now sell in Selfridges for £320 a pop, incidentally: http://www.selfrid...er_704-10170-1513/ )

BE11:16am

So anyway, yesterday was confirmation that the iPhone X uses VCSEL for its camera.

PM11:16am

This is fascinating Bryce

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Isn't it! So it looks like VCSEL will only be in the top of the range model and it's probably only used for the back camera, not the front camera, which is why IQE's off the boil a bit.

BE11:17am

But is IQE a suppler of the silicon? Probably: http://www.iqep.com/markets/photonics/

BE11:17am

Will we have to wait for the teardowns to confirm that? Yes.

11:17 am
PM11:18am

IQE down almost 6% btw

IQE PLC (IQE:LSE): Last: 139.31, down 7.69 (-5.23%), High: 148.00, Low: 135.75, Volume: 7.38m
BE11:18am

Is it right to be disappointed that VCSEL's not in the whole new iPhone range? Maybe.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Because is it likely that where Apple goes, others will follow? Probably. Though not definitely.

BE11:18am

I can't remember much of a rush by other manufacturers to ape 3D Touch since 2015, for example.

BE11:18am

Peel Hunt is shop here, and relentlessly upbeat as you'd expect.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

This marks the real start of adoption of VCSEL technology in the mass-market. IQE, as the dominant outsourced player, with a reputation for delivery, customer service and low cost, is ideally placed to deliver it. The most optimistic may be disappointed that VCSELs are not immediately in all models and both cameras, but this will come in time.

BE11:19am

How well will they sell? (time will tell but the new model is a big step up from the 7, the launch date for the X is not until 3 November, a much longer wait than usual, the price of $999/£999 for a base 64GB iphone is demanding but has been judged based on the value it brings).

BE11:19am

Much remains to be seen, but our mid-case scenario of a taxed 7.5p EPS requires 200m “units”(iphone X equivalent), each with $0.75 of content (end FY18 run rate, which looks a bit high on the current line-up, but this can change), to which we apply a target PER of 20x.

11:18 am
BE11:19am

This is not inconsistent with contribution payback being one year for the investment in new tooling, as recently highlighted by management to investors, which using simple arithmetic would take untaxed EPS to 9p. The stock is likely to be volatile as news flow emerges, hence our TP is only a central case.

BE11:20am

I do like analyst notes with "time will tell" and "much remains to be seen" in them, that then have a buy rating at 150p when the price was 147p.

PM11:20am

hehe

11:20 am
PM11:20am

This stock is actually up about 10 fold over the past year

PM11:20am

£1bn market cap

BE11:21am

Yes, something like that. Because once you land Apple as a supplier it's all milk and honey from that moment onwards. I mean, just look at Imagination.

11:21 am
Imagination Technologies Group PLC (IMG:LSE): Last: 134.50, down 8.5 (-5.94%), High: 148.00, Low: 130.50, Volume: 1.22m
BE11:22am

Otherwise, I've had a bunch of messages telling me to be excited about the iWatch (which still exists, apparently) moving to an ESim, which is a microscopic positive for a sim company we won't mention.

BE11:22am

And that's about it for Apple, I think.

11:22 am
PM11:22am

What main phone are you currently using Bryce?

BE11:23am

Alcatel One Touch.

PM11:23am

Oh

11:23 am
BE11:23am

One Touch 332, the 2003 model. It's slick AF.

undefined
BE11:24am

Actually, before we leave the sector ....

11:24 am
BE11:24am

I'm going to note in passing that there's a disturbance in the force around the French-Italian-Swiss chipmakers.

BE11:25am

And a flood of hot money, of the type that often precedes a story appearing among the rumour aggregation sites.

BE11:25am

I foresee the letters S, T and M .....

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Anyway, good luck to all holders.

undefined
PM11:25am

Should we mention Bitcoin?

11:25 am
PM11:26am

It's down about 8/9% overnight, following Jamie Dimon...

PM11:26am

But it's all the other clown money that's really being clobbered

PM11:26am

Like this thing

11:26 am
PM11:26am

https://coinmarketcap.com/assets/coeval/

PM11:27am

That's the idiot thing pushed by Daniel Harrison

PM11:27am

Who has history with us

11:27 am
PM11:27am

use the search function

PM11:27am

Off 85% overnight

PM11:27am

Such an idiot mania, all of this

11:27 am
undefined
PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

PM11:28am

Dunelm

11:28 am
PM11:28am

Rocket

BE11:28am

Up 7% on a warning.

Dunelm Group PLC (DNLM:LSE): Last: 654.50, up 44 (+7.21%), High: 662.00, Low: 597.00, Volume: 547.19k
11:28 am
PM11:29am

https://www.invest...1709130700055672Q/

BE11:29am

At least, it was a warning in all the copy written before 8am.

BE11:29am

It's now switched to a reassuring update.

11:29 am
PM11:29am

Well, they mentioned the consumer slow down...

PM11:30am

But the sell side seem very positive

BE11:30am

So, PBT down -15% yoy but that was already flagged by the Q4 trading update.

11:30 am
PM11:30am

When John Browett left

BE11:31am

The first bit of the statement, before the caution, does say "an encouraging start to FY18 with good LFL sales growth in the first two months"

BE11:31am

Which is, by any measure, quite positive. Particularly as the statement when Browett exited only noted the caution bit.

11:31 am
BE11:32am

You've also got the headwind of £10.7m of losses from Worldstores for the 31 weeks to 1 July

BE11:33am

Which make the figures look much worse than they'd be otherwise. Guidance is for Worldstores to get close to breakeven in the YE2018.

BE11:33am

.... It remains an odd acquisition, but what do I know. Any sellside here?

11:33 am
PM11:33am

Here's Cantor

PM11:33am

Our view: Today’s FY’17 results are in line with expectations with PBT falling by 15% to £109.3m (vs CFE £109.5m). This includes a £10.7m loss from Worldstores. Management comment that sales in the first two months of the year have started positively, with LFL growth boosted in part by favourable weather conditions. With today’s results in line and a solid start to FY’18 we do not expect any major changes to consensus estimates at this stage with the Q1 update due on 5th October. The search for the new CEO is underway following the announcement last month of John Browett’s departure. We maintain our BUY recommendation with a 780p TP.

PM11:34am

And SInger

11:33 am
PM11:34am

While end markets have weakened, DNLM has the hall-marks of a compelling investment case –

no.1 in a highly fragmented market, significant geographic expansion potential, major investments in infrastructure/systems to drive growth (especially online) and unlock efficiencies, and highly cash generative. But the stock has de-rated to just 11x P/E in response to d/grades, mostly driven by short term losses/costs, which don’t recur. Consensus expects no ‘underlying’ PBT growth in FY18 and RoIC to halve over 3 years, which will only be corrected by either upgrades (+ special returns), or asset write-downs. The latter looks unlikely in our view, whereas payback analysis on investment points to higher growth/PBT vs consensus. Over 2 years the TSR would be 60% in the event DNLM re-rates to 10x EV/EBITDA on this consensus (i.e. base case), including only ordinaries (no specials). Today’s update and positive start to Q1 underpins our assessment that the recent sell off and inflection point represent a great entry point for this stock.

PM11:34am

And Stifel

PM11:34am

Dunelm Final Results are in line with expectations and we are maintaining FY18 estimates. The current year has started well against last year's weak comparisons, in our view. Strategic commentary underlines management's ambitious multichannel vision for the group. The October 11 Capital Markets Day should provide a useful update. On little more than a sector rating with a c.4.5% yield, we believe Dunelm shares offer decent income with genuine growth potential.

11:34 am
PM11:34am

All saying pretty much the same

BE11:34am

Morgan Stanley as well, since we're here.

BE11:35am

- With John Browett having left so abruptly, investor focus today was always likely to be mainly on whether or not there would be a significant change in group strategy. We can detect little sign of one in this statement, however.
- Having spoken with the company this morning, we would expect little change in consensus forecasts for FY 2017/18 today. According to Bloomberg, consensus is currently looking for Pre Tax Profits to £120m in FY 2017/18 (giving 47.7p of EPS) - Based on last night's closing price and existing consensus forecasts, Dunelm is trading on 12.0x Cal 2018 earnings, 8.0x EBITDA, with a 4.5% Dividend Yield. This compares with a UK General Retail sector trading on 12.0x, 7.6x and 4.5% respectively

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Fairly dull retailer, living just below Amazon disruption price points and at a reasonable valuation. I guess there are worse places for your money.

undefined
PM11:37am

Sky's stabilised I see

11:37 am
Sky PLC (SKY:LSE): Last: 936.75, down 0.25 (-0.03%), High: 937.50, Low: 932.00, Volume: 1.41m
BE11:37am

....... Hmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm ..........

PM11:38am

But this deal is surely getting less and less likely?

11:38 am
PM11:38am

Which maybe suits Murdoch

PM11:38am

As you have suggested previously

BE11:39am

I don't know.

11:38 am
BE11:39am

I was always curious about Murdoch's needlessly belligerent approach to due process.

BE11:40am

It never looked a great idea, assuming he wanted the deal to complete, to go in with a sabre rattling.

BE11:40am

...... which led me to speculate that he might not be overly concerned if the deal didn't complete.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

That wasn't, and isn't, a consensus opinion. But then, I'm still a bit lost as to why Fox wants full control of Sky anyway.

BE11:41am

Analysts mostly saying, "it'll get there with remedies".

PM11:41am

Credit Suisse cautious, for what its worth

11:41 am
PM11:41am

Broadcasting standards now in focus: The Secretary of State for DCMS, Karen Bradley, has now stated she is minded to refer the FOX/Sky transaction to the CMA on BOTH plurality grounds and broadcasting standards. Previously she has said she was only minded to refer the deal on media plurality grounds. The parties have 10 days to respond but we think it unlikely that the Secretary of State will change her mind. This does not change the timetable (another 6 months delay), but does suggest to us the CMA will be given significantly more scope for its review including areas of compliance and corporate governance. This raises the hurdle for ultimate approval, in our view because it opens up more avenues for investigation, but does not tip the balance decisively against approval.

PM11:41am

Decision made on judicial grounds and not entirely in line with Ofcom views: In the prior reviews Ofcom said that there were no grounds for a referral to the CMA on broadcasting standards. In their updated advice Ofcom admitted there are "non-fanciful" concerns about broadcast compliance and about corporate governance failures, but declined to say that these were sufficiently serious to merit referral on broadcasting standards grounds. Karen Bradley disagreed with Ofcom on both counts and thinks these concerns should be a matter for the CMA, also arguing the threshold for referral is low. This is despite the recent shut down of Fox News in the UK. On the "Foxification" of Fox News outlets around the world and the risk to standards in the UK, the Secretary of State said this did not raise concerns but the CMA might want to consider this anyway.

PM11:42am

They say the stock could drop to 700p if/when the deal fails

11:42 am
PM11:42am

Valuation: Our PT is still set at the offer price of 1075p (c.14% upside). Our view on the break price or where the stock could trade if the transaction is blocked or the offer is withdrawn is that this price is 700-750p. This is based on comparable valuation, recent financial results and changes in competitive environment.

PM11:42am

A lot of arb blood on the floor if that happens

BE11:42am

Impossible to say, given how much the shareholder base has churned through this process. You'd have a humongous overhang to clear out, and a lot of model refreshing to try and figure out what this thing's even worth.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

And to remind, Sky had one of the most polarised valuation models on the market, between people saying "terminal decline" and those saying "cash cow".

PM11:43am

CS also have a grey sky price

PM11:43am

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Precisely.

undefined
BE11:44am

While on broadcadsters ......

11:44 am
BE11:44am

Bit sector note from Macquarie.

BE11:45am

Selling ITV, and everything else terrestrial.

ITV PLC (ITV:LSE): Last: 159.40, down 1.7 (-1.06%), High: 160.10, Low: 156.40, Volume: 7.35m
11:45 am
BE11:46am

We argue the next decade will be harder than the past one for FTA broadcasters, as new consumer models devalue the mass reach of TV advertising. We would turn buyers again for consolidation and a cyclical upturn, but first we need to see lower consensus estimates.

BE11:46am

As in .....

BE11:46am

Contrary to our previous belief of softening structural headwinds (round one was about media fragmentation), things are getting harder again for FTA broadcasters. Increasing demand for local and craft products diminishes the importance of TV’s most unique advantage, mass advertising. Online purchases (ecommerce already accounts for 3% of GDP) also force advertisers to shift marketing closer to the point of sale, i.e. Amazon. Adidas’ CEO said last March the company was moving away from TV advertising in favour of direct engagement on digital channels.

11:47 am
BE11:48am

"Increasing demand for local and craft products" is a new one on me. TV disrupted by a second coming of John Ruskin and William Morris. Fair enough.

BE11:48am

Weakening operational trends at large Fast Moving Consumer Good (FMCG) and Retail companies translated into sizeable cuts to A&P budgets that already hit the advertising agencies (e.g. WPP’s drop post Unilever cuts). The consumer sector accounts for a disproportionately large share of TV ad revenues (40%-50% vs 25%/ 30% for advertising agencies) so any reduction on media spending will have a magnified impact on FTA broadcasters.

BE11:48am

In spite of a decline in TV viewing and shrinking audience share, pressure on free TV incumbents diminished over the past ten years. Increased scarcity of mass audience in a fragmenting media landscape allowed FTA broadcasters to raise prices faster than competitors (TV CPM inflation 2x/3x higher than print/online since 2010). But that means a higher value gap and the risk of sharper corrections if the consumer sector pressure increases.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

And as for ITV .....

BE11:48am

We are cutting our 2017-18E EPS for European FTA broadcasters on average by 2% and 9% and we are now at the bottom of consensus range. Our through-the-cycle TV advertising revenue growth assumptions are now based on GDP minus 200bps and broadly stable margins.
We believe take-over scenarios for ITV, Mediaset and Mediaset Espana are now less relevant, and trading multiples are still relatively high. We need to see the new structural concerns reflected in consensus estimates before turning more positive: we downgrade all three to Underperform rating (Table 1) and we reaffirm our Underperform rating for Prosieben. In the US we remain buyers of CBS, thanks to its successful diversification strategy in direct-to-consumer OTT services; advertising is already down to 40% of total revenues.

BE11:49am

All of which is familiar stuff to readers of, for example, Campling at Northern Trust.

11:49 am
undefined
BE11:50am

ROTR, I've absolutely no idea about this Glencore-Rio theory.

Rio Tinto PLC (RIO:LSE): Last: 3,659, down 32 (-0.87%), High: 3,679, Low: 3,631, Volume: 1.07m
11:50 am
Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 366.20, down 6.3 (-1.69%), High: 369.45, Low: 364.15, Volume: 14.70m
PM11:50am

Hang on Bryce! You are the one who has given this legs!

PM11:50am

https://www.ft.com...-b83c-9588e51488a0

11:50 am
BE11:50am

I did not! It's fantasy M&A! It's fantasy M&A from Alphavalue!

BE11:50am

Speak to them! I assume they have phones.

PM11:51am

You were just reporting the fact -- dont shoot the messenger

11:51 am
PM11:51am

Omg smile

BE11:52am

Sometimes, fantasy M&A plays out. Sometimes it doesn't, and it's just a convenient thing to put at the top of a stock market report on a quiet Tuesday in September.

BE11:53am

It also throws BHP into the mix, though I didn't have room to quote that bit.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

While Glencore’s interest for acquisitions (including Rio) was never hidden from the markets. With their balance sheet in a much stronger state now (gearing of 43% at 2017e vs. 83% in 2014), any concerns from Rio’s side (lingering since 2014) too should have moderated by now. Even though BHP Billiton could have been another option (commodity portfolio-wise), but its struggling oil assets, strategic lop-sidedness and Samarco uncertainties are good enough deterrents.

BE11:54am

And in terms of rationale .....

BE11:54am

Rio’s largest shareholder is Chalco (Chinese state-owned aluminium major) while a sizeable part (c.22%) of Glencore is owned by its management – including CEO Ivan Glasenberg’s 8.4% stake. Given the Chinese state’s objective of garnering increasing (ownership) control over the world’s natural resources, as evident from a slew of deals struck over the past many years, Chalco ideally should not object to a combination. After all, it would own a mining behemoth, with a combined market cap of greater than £110bn (comparable with BHP’s peak market cap in 2011), that has sizeable control over
aluminium, copper, coal, iron ore and zinc mining capacities, apart from being able to access a world-class trading platform. It would also get to leverage the mining prowess of Ivan Glasenberg and his team.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

I think they mean Chinalco rather than Chalco, but Chinese miners confuse me so perhaps it's me that's getting that wrong.

undefined
BE11:56am

So ....... what else? Paul's having to run off to something important.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

And I've lost track of requests, having mostly ignored them for 55 minutes.

BE11:56am

(No offence, ROTR.)

BE11:58am

(@Borncynic: nothing today, but I promise to come back to it tomorrow.)

11:58 am
BE11:58am

There's a big food retail thing out from Exane .....

BE11:59am

Andrew Gwynn's the analyst.

BE11:59am

A return to rational pricing behaviour would seem to signal that there’s life in UK food retail. With the era of capex at 2x depreciation hopefully behind us, cash should flow. The problem for shareholders is that they are at the back of a queue of liabilities which can be hard to measure and once at the front, there’s Amazon to deal with. Fear is familiar in food retail and is mostly captured in valuation we think. However, Tesco’s recent bounce again skews risk / reward to the downside and we return it (and so Booker) to Underperform. Morrisons (+) remains our favoured UK name.

11:59 am
BE12:00pm

Having discussed the retail challenges a few times recently, in this note we focus on the balance sheets of the UK food retailers. For Tesco, our principal concern is the large pension deficit (c60p per share) as there’s really only one certainty; it’s impossible to calculate precisely. However, the deficit seems likely to be stubborn. Having seen the shares rebound over the last two months, (c15% against the sector) we return our rating to Underperform but hold our 165p TP steady. We also return our definition of EPS to one that captures the pension cost (cutting EPS but not EBIT).

Tesco PLC (TSCO:LSE): Last: 181.45, down 3.6 (-1.95%), High: 182.90, Low: 180.75, Volume: 10.82m
Booker Group PLC (BOK:LSE): Last: 198.40, down 5.3 (-2.60%), High: 201.40, Low: 197.70, Volume: 2.53m
12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Morrisons (+, 270p TP) has comfortably the strongest balance sheet of the Big 4 (it owns 90% of its store estate and there’s a net pension asset) and we remain of the view that buybacks are likely. Coupled with continued improvements in the offer, a favourable format mix, catch-up potential in fast growing, higher margin categories like organics, not to mention cost saving, we think the business is the most attractive of the UK food retailers.

WM Morrison Supermarkets PLC (MRW:LSE): Last: 243.40, down 0.3 (-0.12%), High: 243.60, Low: 240.30, Volume: 1.87m
BE12:01pm

Sainsbury’s (=, 250p TP) balance sheet has major challenges like Tesco but expectations are very different; the valuation multiple difference making that clearest (9.6x March-19E EV/EBIT versus 13.5x). At present, the LFL spread between the Big 4 is the narrowest we can remember so having chided Sainsbury’s for underperforming, we’re not sure the valuation spread is fair.

12:01 pm
J Sainsbury PLC (SBRY:LSE): Last: 238.50, down 0.6 (-0.25%), High: 239.10, Low: 237.30, Volume: 1.44m
BE12:01pm

If you want the rest, pay for it. Good analysts have to eat.

BE12:01pm

(As do bad analysts, I guess, but we're less worried about them.)

12:01 pm
undefined
BE12:02pm

(@sprout: thanks. The whole Russian doll thing they have going on over there gives me a headache.)

BE12:02pm

And on eSure, that's UBS. Another sector thing.

12:02 pm
esure Group PLC (ESUR:LSE): Last: 258.00, down 6.1 (-2.31%), High: 261.60, Low: 249.40, Volume: 487.30k
BE12:03pm

We see headwinds increasing for Esure due to: (1) lower margin on new risk segments it is expanding into; (2) early Ogden reinsurance renewals; and (3) releases below guidance due to reduced reserve conservatism on new business. Our work on the earnings profiles of the core book and additional footprints affirms this view. Furthermore, the risk to Esure's growth from a lower price growth environment is higher than peers, in our view. We think the current valuation (14x 2017E PE) underappreciates these risks, and we see downside to consensus earnings (UBSe c15% below consensus from 2019E). We continue to view special dividends as unlikely, and as such, we also see downside risk to dividend expectations. We see better risk/reward opportunities elsewhere in the sector.

BE12:04pm

In the new risk segments Esure is expanding into, it is targeting (and so far reporting) absolute per policy profit at least as high as its lower risk core book. Given average premiums are 40-70% higher, this implies lower margins. We have reduced earnings by 5-15% as this expansion drags on margins, combined with increased reinsurance costs (Esure renewed ahead of Ogden rate change proposal). Our combined ratio expectations for motor now rapidly diverge from consensus from 2018E. Furthermore, given footprint expansion, we see risk as skewed to the downside versus our base case.

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

Growth requires capital – with Esure's capital drag having remained consistent over the last two years (around 30% of forward premium), our growth and margin expectations do not leave Esure with sufficient capital generation to pay special dividends. We therefore see downside risk to market expectations for continued special dividends.
